Award.AwardTitle: Core-Ligand Interfacial Bond Structure Defined Metal Nanoclusters and the Energetics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) program of the Division of Chemistry will support the research program of Prof. Gangli Wang of Georgia State University. Prof. Wang and his students will synthesize and characterize the properties of gold and copper nanoclusters that are capped with multi-dentate thiols for chemical stabilization. The energetics of metal nanoclusters will be investigated with optical and electrochemical techniques. Nano-sized electrodes will be fabricated to quantitatively study the electron transfer kinetics in these nanoclusters. A correlation will be established between the energetics and functionality of metal nanoclusters and their compositions and structures.

The project will address basic questions and issues that are at the heart of many fields such as energy, nanoscience, surface science, and chemistry. The structure-property correlation established on gold and copper nanoclusters could potentially reveal the active sites in catalytic processes. The nanoclusters could also be used in photovoltaics devices. The proposed research will provide state-of-the-art education and training opportunities for students in this cutting edge, interdisciplinary research area.

Institution.Name: Georgia State University Research Foundation, Inc.
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: GEORGIA STATE UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is provided for NSF 1059022 entitled “Core-Ligand Interfacial Bond Structure Defined Metal Nanoclusters and the Energetics”. In this project, the students and PI have synthesized several metal clusters stabilized by a monolayer of organic molecules with desired thiol and dithiol functionality. The molecular structures and electronic orbitals are selected such that they might interact with the unique metal core and display novel properties otherwise inaccessible. This interaction, refereed as electronic coupling, will establish a new paradigm to tailor the properties and functions of this exciting category of functional nanomaterials and advance their applications in, i.e. biosensing, cell imaging, charge storage, catalysis and other energy applications. This grant has allowed the PI to continue teaching and mentoring students from high school to graduate levels. ACS high school students through the SEED program, undergraduate students through the NSF REU program, and several underrepresented students in the chemistry department at Georgia State University have performed cutting edge research in this fast growing scientific field. The PI has also advanced the chemistry curriculum in his course instruction of Electrochemistry and Quantitative Analysis by introducing various electrochemistry concepts and technologies. Students participated in this project are pursuing graduate educations (several undergraduate students), developed skill sets and found industrial positions (M. S. students), performing postdoc research (Ph. D. students) and established independent academic career (Ph. D. students and postdocs). 

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2015
Modified by: Gangli Wang
